item.title: French Minister Feared Equity Trading Exodus to UK After Dividend Tax Rule Change
item.description: France’s finance minister said he feared a “mass exodus” of equity trading to London if he hadn’t provided clarity to banks about the application of new dividend tax rules.
item.dc:creator: Gaspard Sebag

item.title: EU to Protect Airbus in US Trade Deal as Ferrari Set to Lose Out
item.description: As the European Union nears a trade deal with the US, its negotiators are focusing on protecting key industries from massive tariffs set to hit the bloc’s exports as soon as Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Benedikt Kammel, Stefan Nicola

media:content.media:description: An aircraft assembled at an Airbus manufacturing plant.

item.title: US Trims 2025 Crude Output Growth Forecast as Drilling Stalls
item.description: The US sees domestic crude output growth slowing more than expected this year as choppy oil prices limit drilling activity.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: Liberty Lift Solutions LLC pumpjacks near Crane, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch.

item.title: Gold Declines as Market Parses Trump Comments on Tariff Deadline
item.description: Gold dropped as investors parsed President Donald Trump’s decision to delay the start of increased duties on several trading partners, while insisting the new deadline is final.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Elise Harris

item.title: Celebrity-Backed Vegan Leather Startup to Tap Muni Market in Test of Risk Appetite
item.description: A vegan-leather start up is slated to tap the municipal bond market this week, marking a test of investor confidence in speculative project finance.
item.dc:creator: Erin Hudson, Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: MycoWorks production facility in Union, South Carolina.

item.title: Franco-German Rift Risks Dooming Next Fighter Jet, BDLI Says
item.description: A rift between French and German companies over control of a next-generation fighter jet risks dooming the project, Germany’s aviation lobby said, putting in doubt a marquee program just as the region fortifies its defense capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Kirchfeld, Benedikt Kammel

media:content.media:description: A model of an FCAS aircraft in Madrid.

item.title: Bank of America Lifts S&P 500 Target on Corporate America’s Resilience
item.description: Bank of America Corp. strategists boosted their outlook for US equities, citing the Corporate America’s ability to maintain earnings guidance in the face of President Donald Trump’s chaotic trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

item.title: Russia Bans Yale University Activity in Country as ‘Undesirable’
item.description: Russian authorities declared Yale University to be an “undesirable” organization, banning its activities in the country.
item.dc:creator: Andrey Lemeshko

media:content.media:description: The Yale University campus in New Haven, Connecticut,.

item.title: Stocks Fluctuate as Traders Assess a Slew of Trade Developments
item.description: US equities swung between small gains and losses in midday trading Tuesday, with traders’ initial hope for further negotiations on tariffs dashed as President Donald Trump said he would not offer any extensions to a new August 1 deadline.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Stocks Halt Trade-Fueled Slide on Hopes for Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks halted their slide as hopes President Donald Trump is still open to trade talks offset his remarks that the US won’t offer extensions to the August deadline for reciprocal tariffs to kick in. Treasuries joined a global slide of longer-dated bonds. The dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Containers next to gantry cranes at a shipping terminal in Yokohama, Japan, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release trade figures on April 17. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: HSBC Expands UK Wealth Bet in Race to £100 Billion Asset Goal
item.description: HSBC Holdings Plc is ramping up growth plans for its UK wealth-management operations as Europe’s largest bank seeks to double the assets it oversees for well-heeled individuals in its home nation.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Stupples, Harry Wilson

media:content.media:description: An HSBC Holdings bank branch in St. Albans, UK.

item.title: BOJ Faces Inflation Risks and Has Room for Hikes, Nakaso Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan must be vigilant to upside inflation risks and has room to hike interest rates further, according to former Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Hiroshi Nakaso, chairman of Daiwa Institute of Research Ltd., speaks at the FinCity Global Forum in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. The event is part of a financial promotion project by FinCity.Tokyo, an organization set up to boost the attractiveness of Tokyo as a financial center. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Uber Traders Shrug Off Robotaxi Risks as Stock Powers to Record
item.description: Uber Technologies Inc. investors are brushing aside potential threats from self-driving competition to bet that the company has plenty of room to expand in the near term.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: NFT Market Falls Fifth-Straight Quarter, Trading Volumes Plummet
item.description: Nonfungible tokens, once a burgeoning scene for crypto traders and enthusiasts, seem to have lost much of their allure as trading volumes in the once-hot sector have now declined for the fifth straight quarter.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Ogunrinde

item.title: Greece’s Depa Reaches Settlement With Gazprom on Gas Pricing
item.description: Greek state gas distributor Depa Commercial SA reached an out-of-court agreement with Russia’s Gazprom PJSC on the pricing of supplies following an international arbitration.
item.dc:creator: Paul Tugwell

media:content.media:description: A Gazprom PJSC gas drilling rig tower in the Kovyktinskoye gas field near Irkutsk, Russia.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 7/8/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Viktor Shvets on Why Investors Shouldn’t Worry Too Much about the AI Bubble
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: App icons for ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok and DeepSeek on a smartphone arranged in Riga, Latvia, on Monday, June 9, 2025. Announced in March, XAI Holdings was created from the combination of X, formerly Twitter, and Musk’s AI venture, xAI. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Smelter Mishap Stokes Shutdown Push at Top Copper Miner Codelco
item.description: A recent mishap at a century-old copper smelter owned by Codelco is stoking debate over the pros and cons of shutting it down as a global smelting glut puts pressure on old, high-cost plants.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

media:content.media:description: Molten copper pours into ceramic molds to form plates at a copper smelter facility

item.title: Wall Street’s Southern Shift: Attracting Banks to Texas
item.description: Ari Rastegar, CEO of Rastegar Capital, says commercial real estate is in a transitional phase that can disrupt New York’s monopoly on capital markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: If Housing Crashes So Will the Stock Market Says Brad Case
item.description: Brad Case, Chief Economist at Middleburg Communities, joins Bloomberg Surveillance joins to talk about pressures on a frozen housing market, whether the Fed is behind the curve, and the risks of reigniting inflation. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Treasuries Extend Drop as Pressures Build on Longer-Dated Debt
item.description: US Treasuries fell for a fifth day as demand for long-term government debt across the globe wanes amid a flurry of bond auctions this week.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Greg Ritchie

item.title: Hamilton Lane's Hirsch Sees 'Choppy' Summer for US Stocks
item.description: Erik Hirsch, Hamilton Lane co-CEO, says the disconnect between US stocks and the fixed income bears watching. Speaking on "Bloomberg Open Interest," Hirsch also says the private market is becoming bifurcated. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Swings as Traders Assess Trump Tariffs, Red Sea Attacks
item.description: Oil fluctuated as traders weighed President Donald Trump’s latest wave of tariff threats against fresh tensions in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Mia Gindis

item.title: Goldman Sachs Raises S&P 500 Target by 11%
item.description: Goldman Sachs strategists lifted their 12-month forecast for the S&P 500 index to 6,900 and increased the year-end target to 6,600, citing lower Treasury yields and strength in large US companies. Jan-Patrick Barnert has more on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: BlackRock’s Lynam Says Corporate Credit Still Attractive
item.description: “There’s a case for selectively moving down in credit quality,” Amanda Lynam, BlackRock’s head of credit macro research, says on “Bloomberg Surveillance.”

item.title: Soccer Investor Claims ‘Rogue Banker’ Cover-Up Ruined Merger
item.description: Embattled football club owner John Textor and his backers are suing each other over a failed merger, with allegations that the American businessman was deceived over connections to sanctioned Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier, Giles Turner

media:content.media:description: John Textor Photographer: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Canadian Mining Magnate Seeks US Projects as Trump Deregulates
item.description: Canadian mining magnate Frank Giustra is scouring for projects in the US as President Donald Trump cuts red tape and the outlook for metals like copper and gold remains bright.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

item.title: Wall Street Bank Stocks’ Furious Rally Spurs HSBC Downgrades
item.description: HSBC is turning cautious on three of the biggest US bank stocks following a record rally that’s brought the group within shouting distance of an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: A HSBC bank branch in Enfield, UK.

item.title: BP Plans to Keep Crude Unit at German Refinery Running for Now
item.description: BP Plc will for now keep running a crude-processing unit that it had planned to close at its Gelsenkirchen refinery — the bigger of its two plants in Germany — as the market contributes to the plant’s profitability.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Graham

media:content.media:description: An oil refinery operated by BP in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.

item.title: LVMH Names Long-Time Arnault Associate to Fix Americas Unit
item.description: LVMH named Michael Burke to head its Americas operations, bringing back an old-time fixer to take on some of the biggest challenges the group has faced in the region.
item.dc:creator: Angelina Rascouet
